title: Methodology of Critical Editions: Mieczysław Surzyński’s Concerto for Organ and Orchestra op. 35

abstracts.content:
Currently, New Musicology embraces almost every direction of humanistic study,
including the most recent intermedia and interdisciplinary research suitable for
integration with music scholarship. Its rapid advancement proves the need for a
continued development of new research tools and systematized terminologies. Earlier heuristic studies that led to the release of critical editions and scholarly musical manuscripts are, however, still being undertaken and, it seems, will not go “out of fashion”. Hence the needs of contemporary recipients of musical scores find their answer in the scholarly edition supplemented with a clear and graphically highlighted performance interpretation. This article presents the methodology of editing the manuscript copy of the Concerto for Organ and Orchestra op. 35 (1904) by the Polish composer Mieczysław Surzyński, which led to the production of a contemporary critical edition of this work intended for contemporary performers and students of organ.

title: Bordering on monodrama… Madame Curie by Elżbieta Sikora

abstracts.content:
The subject of analysis is the contemporary opera Madame Curie (2010) by the Polish composer Elżbieta Sikora, premiered in 2011 in Paris. In an extremely 
emotional way, using innovative techniques for expression, the composer tells the story of the scientist Maria Skłodowska-Curie in the form of a script for the opera, with anxiety as the main idea of the libretto. This dramatic work is an example of an intermedia work in which the composer uses electronic media alongside traditional instruments. The composition is an intermedia spectacle revealing the symbolic significance of the sound emission interacting with the libretto, choreography, lighting, ancient Greek theatre form and an electronic medium.
Despite being divided into scenes, the piece was directed using a single set representing the laboratory of the Polish Nobel Prize winner. The director patterned the staging of this opera after Greek theatre: for action on stage, the whole proscenium was used, and the orchestra was seated at the back of the stage (not in the orchestra pit), the soloists at the front, next to the spectators, while the conductor led the ensemble with the help of a video camera, not seeing the soloists. The chorus was amphitheatrically seated on chairs on both sides of the stage to follow the action on stage with the eye of a censor. Every role required of its actor great craft, extraordinary skill and professionalism.The aim of the presentation will have been a multi-aspect analysis and interpretation of the score and the recording of the opera, as well as a discussion of the characteristics of voice projection in this complex work.The article presents a comprehensive analysis and interpretation of the opera’s score and recordng.

title: Koncert na organy i klawesyn Ester Mägi

abstracts.content: Ester Mägi (1922–2021) is one of the important figures of twentieth-century Estonian music. The ‘first lady of Estonian music’ has never adopted the avant-garde techniques, following her strong inclination for tradition. Tradition is a major source of inspiration for her music, first through neoclassicism, then through postmodernism, but overall and most importantly through her interest in Estonian folklore. Mägi is an author of several works for solo organ and of several other chamber works that include organ. One of the latter is her Concerto for organ and harpsichord written in 1980. One of several organ concertos by Estonian composers, it is still rather unique thanks to its unconventional composition. Featuring instruments of vastly different acoustic characteristics and abilities, it takes on a challenge of applying the concerto technique to the type of texture that tends to rely on solos rather than tuttis. Considering the aspect of form, Mägi’s work refers to the formal model of the traditional concerto due to its three movements, an apparent reference to the rondo in the third movement and certain elements of the sonata form in the first movement. The characteristics of melody and rhythm involve limited scale material, repetitiveness of melodic formulas with variation and progression, predominance of specific intervals, particularly minor third and prominence of intervallic structures, which makes Mägi’s Concerto an remarkably coherent work.

title: In memoriam Jeanne Demessieux w 100. rocznicę urodzin kompozytorki

abstracts.content: The subject of this article is the life and music of the outstanding French organist and composer Jeanne Demessieux (1921–1968), whose 100th anniversary of birth falls in 2021. She was undoubtedly one of the greatest musicians of the twentieth century, astounding in her play with her uncanny technical ability, improvisation, delivering from memory inspired performances of the most difficult pieces in the organ repertoire of different periods. At her concerts, she gathered thousands of listeners, and her students included outstanding organists. Demessieux’s organ music is a fusion of tradition and modernity; of French symphonic music and Gregorian chant, and modern musical language. The aim of this article is also to present Demessieux’s music little-known in Poland and to promote the study of her pieces.

title: Twórczość Henri’ego Dutilleux na instrumenty dęte drewniane jako wyraz poszukiwania własnego stylu

abstracts.content: Henri Dutilleux’s early music for woodwinds is highly valued in teaching. It is not surprising, as the compositions were written in part for this purpose. The composer himself dislike them to such an extent that he forbade the recording of Sonatina for flute and piano in France. Regardless, all the pieces are not only of great pedagogical value, but also extremely interesting in musical terms. Moreover, they are an important field of experimentation for a composer who, based on the experience gained, evolves his signature style. On their basis, it is possible to trace the applied solutions, as well as a number of references and inspirations for the development of an individual expressive idiom.

title: Wysłyszeć głosy tradycji… Concerto Festivo Dariusza Przybylskiego

abstracts.content: The subject of this article is Dariusz Przybylski’s work for two soloists (organ/positive) and chamber ensemble, or Concerto Festivo for organ for two performers and chamber orchestra op. 46, specially commissioned for the second edition of the ‘Per Arte ad Astra’ Organ Music Festival in Krasnobród. The point of departure for critical considerations is an analysis of the composition that would reveal any references to tradition as well as any patterns etablished by the latter. Within the scope of its large-scale structure, the composition draws on the Baroque chamber concerto model (concerto da camera) whose cycle order resembles that of a suite. This justifies the small selection, in the tutti, of such instruments as the strings and the flute. Such simplification, however, does not apply to the solo parts which, engaged in a dialogue with one another, demonstrate their virtuoso and expressive performance capability. For the soloists were entrusted with developing the musical narrative. The concertante and showpiece role of the solo instruments, a determinant of the Classical concerto, accompanies Przybylski’s own creative ideas. For a better understanding of the means of musical expression used by the composer, applied was the concept of stylization, one of the intertextual strategies borrowed from the Polish literary scholar Stanisław Balbus.

title: „Oscylacje multifoniczne” w grze na flecie – przykład nowych możliwości brzmieniowych osiąganych połączeniem współczesnych technik sonorystycznych

abstracts.content: The purpose of this lecture is to present an unusual and rarely encountered combination of the modern extended sonoristic techniques, providing many interesting tonal possibilities. It consists of combining multiphonics with finger vibrato. The author proposes to name the technique ‘multiphonic oscillation’. The gist thereof is to expand the multiphonic capabilities of the flute by applying unusual fingerings, often making use of partial uncovering of the keyholes and finger vibrato. This means a little regular opening and closing of the keyhole by a slight movement of the finger, producing the effect of pronounced vibrato. Apart from the multiphonics and oscillation, also produced are quarter-tones and microtones, and an effect close to bisbigliando. It is also possible to play with air noise (aeolian tones) as well as the bending tones

title: Wieloaspektowość gry na instrumentach klawiszowych w edukacji muzyka kościelnego na przykładzie kształcenia organistów w specjalności muzyka kościelna w Akademii Muzycznej im. Stanisława Moniuszki w Gdańsku

abstracts.content: Umiejętność obsługi instrumentów klawiszowych (głównie organów) jest w polskiej rzeczywistości muzyka kościelnego fundamentalną kompetencją warunkującą podjęcie pracy zawodowej w strukturach kościelnych. Specjalność muzyka kościelna w gdańskiej Akademii Muzycznej, wychodząc naprzeciw tym wyzwaniom, oferuje bardzo zróżnicowany i kompleksowy zestaw zagadnień, które umożliwiają nie tylko dalszy rozwój osobom posiadającym podstawowe wykształcenie w tym zakresie, lecz także nabycie odpowiednich kompetencji tym, którzy dopiero zaczynają swoją przygodę z organami. Autor przedstawia i analizuje poszczególne aspekty nauczania związanego z grą na instrumentach klawiszowych na tej specjalności. W dalszej części omawia problemy związane z kształceniem organistów, wynikające z uwarunkowań wewnętrznych i zewnętrznych – systemowych oraz instytucjonalnych, postulując w niektórych aspektach określone działania. Artykuł jest analizą sytuacji i warunków kształcenia w roku 2017.

title: Albion – remix intermedia project

abstracts.content:
In a contemporary world defined by technological advances, combining 
different disciplines of the arts to reach the viewer through multiple channels of 
perception is becoming i ncreasingly common and interesting, emblematic 
phenomenon. Syncretic activities on the borderline of composition, improvisation, 
interpretation, and sensory experience of the emerging work expand the areas of 
creative creation. The interdisciplinary approach deepens artistic awareness 
and encourages experimentation, bringing together diverse artistic communities to shape a space for multidimensional collaboration. The Albion project was inspired by British composer Thomas Adès' music. This audiovisual work is a collaboration between a music choreographer and a visual artist. The premise of the Albion - remix project is an attempt to give a new quality to an earlier creation, in which the guiding idea was to 'hear and see' music through the 
prism of the virtual world. The means of expression sought were focused on 
creating a work in which the music and all its elements become a stimulus for 
movement interpretation, as well as all visual activities, creating an integrated 
polymedia artistic message. The project was realised outdoors, where the natural 
environment influenced the artistic decisions made - becoming one of the 
elements of the creative work. By projecting animations onto spatial 
objects, they were given new dimensions and/or brought to life. The resulting
project was recorded and used to further explore both the music and the visual 
and movement layers. Using the previously recorded work, the focus was
on finding a kind of dialogue between what was recorded and the new idea. 
The resulting form of the image corresponds with the earlier recording, while deforming it through visual treatments to create a kind of artistic cognitive hybrid. The live movement blends into the background of the projection through a kind of image manipulation resulting from the animation's reaction to the performer's 
movement. The course of the performer's movement is a planned composition with elements of improvisation resulting from the need to shape the image of the 
emerging projection. Each of the assumptions made was intended to show 
the dynamics of the creative process resulting in an interdisciplinary, generative aesthetic work.

title: Tria na organy i dwa akordeony W. Nowaka, J. Rabińskiego i W. Słowińskiego – inspiracje, konkretyzacje, rezonanse

abstracts.content: Trios for organ and two accordions, as a new form of chamber music which started in 1987 when the first four pieces, were premiered at Organ Conversatorium in Legnica, a festival of contemporary organ music. In 1991 three more were presented: Pneumatofania by Wojciech Nowak, La fontaine de joie by Jacek Rabiński and Translacja by Władysław Słowiński. They are exemplifications of distinctive styles, musical structure and programme music. These seven trios have been recorded and published as CDs or DVD, i.e. a unique project from 2006 made in Gdańsk. The repertoire for organ and two accordions has been expanded in the recent years thanks to the activity of duoAccosphere.

title: W poszukiwaniu sonorystycznej spójności. Kilka słów o projekcie AerOphonic – music for accordion and organ

abstracts.content: The tree symbolises the common roots that connect our instruments, as the organ and the accordion belong to a family of keyboard aerophones. In this community – as in any family – one will find both similarities and differences, which are the greatest stimuli for inspiration, for it is precisely diversity that enriches our common sphere of activity. AerOphonic is a rare combination of two instruments that has led the authors to explore new sounds, new textural and timbral solutions, as well as to use the many possibilities for expression of the accordion and the organ. As musicians with an intimate connection to Pomerania, the authors would like to invite the listeners to join them on a journey through the rich palette of colours and historical shades of that region. The album resounds with the mesmerising sounds of the ancient Oliwa tablature and the breath of freedom that spreads from Gdańsk to the whole world (‘Die Ganzen Welt’). As children of postmodernism, the authors do not shy away from anything that fascinates them artistically, which is why one will also find there elements of Gregorian chant, jazz, film music and also a wonderful piece by César Franck, with which, in the authors’ case, everything began. AerOphonic is a musical journey.

abstracts.content: In this article, the author describes four songs by the Gdansk composer Stanislaw Kwiatkowski (1930–2010). The following songs – O salutaris Hostia, Antiphon for Communion, Christe Redemptor and Heart Opened with a Spear – are small-scale works for four-part mixed choir a cappella. Their analysis allows us to conclude that, both in terms of the semantic layer and musical issues, these works have the typical traits of sacred works which can be performed during liturgy in the church.

title: Chóralne oblicze sacrum i profanum w War Requiem op. 66 Benjamina Brittena

otherTitles.title: The Choral Aspects of the Sacred and Profane in Benjamin Britten’s War Requiem Op. 66

abstracts.content: The article is devoted to Benjamin Britten’s work War Requiem op. 66, considered one of the most important oratorios of the 20th century. The author discusses Britten’s life and music, focusing on his oratorio-cantata and choral works. She then analyses the elements of the sacred and profane in the work discussed in the context of the choral passages, which play an important role. The composition is an intersection of two contradictory tendencies: tradition and modernity. On the one hand, there is a sacred Latin text, and on the other, the secular war poetry of Wilfred Owen. The author presents the genesis of the work and discusses the individual links of the War Requiem from a musical and literary angle.

title: Antyczne i biblijno-patrystyczne źródła teologicznego znaczenia chóru

otherTitles.title: The Ancient and Biblical-Patristic Sources of the Theological Significance of the Choir

abstracts.content: The aim of the article is to present the ancient and biblical-patristic sources of the theological significance of the choir. Therefore, a source analysis of the oldest historical evidence of communal singing was undertaken. Choralism is a phenomenon dating back to the very beginning of human history. Singing together was very common in all aspects of life events as an expression of both sadness and joy. Choral singing played a special role in religion, becoming an expression of contact with the sacred sphere. People sang to God when they experienced misery and tribulation, but also joy and deliverance. To understand the genesis of the theological choir, one must refer to the ancient tradition, especially the Greco-Roman tradition, but above all to the biblical books and the writings of the Fathers of the Church.

otherTitles.title: The Implementation of the Organ Building Project in the Franciscan Church of the Assumption of the Blessed Virgin Mary in Vilnius

abstracts.content: Through the centuries, organ building has always been an event of great social, cultural and artistic importance. The organs are a kind of litmus test of the wealth and cultural openness of a community. It is no different in the case of the reconstruction of the organ in the Franciscan church in Vilnius. The intricate history of the monastery itself and its instruments has drawn a full circle. Visually, the instrument built refers to its predecessors in this place, and musically it tries to combine the traditions of historical organ construction in the territory of present-day Lithuania with the Baltic influences, creating a new artistic and timbral quality. In the article I will present the original assumptions of the rebuilding programme for the organ in the Franciscan Church of the Assumption of the Blessed Virgin Mary in Vilnius.

title: Edukacja muzyczna dzieci na Białorusi – próba komparatystyki aktualnych rozwiązań systemowych

otherTitles.title: The Music Education of Children in Belarus: An Attempt to Compare the Current Systemic Solutions

abstracts.content: Comparisons of education systems in different countries, related to their political, economic and socio-cultural development, is an area of research in the comparative pedagogy field of expertise. Based on the findings and concepts of this pedagogical subdiscipline, the text compares the systems of general music education for children in Poland and Belarus. A brief historical outline shows how the music education systems of Poland, the Russian Empire and the Soviet Union operated in different periods of history in the contemporary territory of Belarus. The development and evolution of the basic music education system in independent Belarus from the beginning of the 1990s to the present day is also discussed. The reform of 1998-2008 tried to transform the structure and content of the Soviet system towards expanding the self-government of educational institutions and introducing European standards, but its results were not consolidated by further actions of state decision-makers. The education system still retains the structure of the Soviet system. A positive feature of the modern education system is the availability of extra music education, because in Belarus there is an extensive network of music schools for children. Curricula and textbooks, developed by pedagogical experts, are largely based on national music; Belarusian folklore. The problems and issues subjected to deep reflection include the gradual reduction in the number of hours of the Music subject in primary schools, the lack of professional teachers, and the decreasing number of pupils in small towns and villages. The described problems reflect general European trends.

title: Technika wokalna i sztuka aktorska w partii Amneris w operze Aida Giuseppe Verdiego

otherTitles.title: Vocal technique and the art of acting in the Amneris's part of the Opera Aida by Giuseppe Verdi

abstracts.content: Verdian leading roles are an important issue in vocalism, both in terms of performance and vocal pedagogy. The part of Amneris in Giuseppe Verdi’s opera Aida is a dream part for many mezzo-soprano singers. However, it is an extremely difficult challenge that requires careful thought and preparation. In her article, the author – based her own stage experience – tries to handle this substantial role, present requirements for performaning the part of Amneris, her character in the opera and the motives that drive her. The author carries out a  comprehensive analysis of the part at the musical and literary level, methods of voice leading, handling registers, timbres, colours, articulation, diction, formulating a synthesis in the form of numerous conclusions. The analytical part is preceded by the genesis of the work and its content. Analysed are the individual, most important sections of the Amneris’s part. The final section contains a summary and conclusions.

title: To See the Invisible. Inphrastic Inspirations by Night  Nature Photography. From Photography to  Audiovisual Composition

abstracts.content:
The composition To See the Invisible for the six performers by Katarzyna Kwiecień-Długosz selected for discussion is an artistic inphrasis showing an artistic representation of the content and emotions previously existing in the 
philosophy and photography of Georg Shiras, and later in the painting of Aneta 
Kublik. The resulting artistic artefact is an emotional reference to the work of art 
from which the painter, and then the composer, drew inspiration. The modification of one code to another occurs in a s ymbolic space, which is related to the phenomenon of the mutual permeation of arts and the expression of 
a non-verbal work. The subject of Aneta Kublik's paintings is the feeling of anxiety 
and suffering caused by frightened roe deer. The original painting technique 
used, based on t he clash between light and black oil paint applied in a sculptural 
manner, caused the symbolic meaning to cross its original boundaries: the calm of 
the deer in the forest. The aesthetic experience at hand i s about lyrical 
abstraction hidden in philosophy and inspiration drawn from another work of 
art. Inside the painter, at the moment of this experience, the vision develops of 
the artistic work.The emotions contained in these paintings by Kublik were later reflected in the audio-visual composition by Katarzyna Kwiecień-Długosz. During the playback of the music material, the paintings are displayed that complete the 
narrative, creating an i ntermedial composition. The musical work contains 
various intermedial references; it uses and is inspired by three sources: 
photographic, painterly and philosophical. Yet the symbolic structure of the composition refers to the painting, and the music material suggests to the 
audience a transition from darkness to lightness with changing moods and 
colours,

title: INTERMEDIA NARRATIVE AND PERCEPTIO SENSATIO IN MUSIC CHOREOGRAPHY

abstracts.content:
The aim of the article is to consider the question: what do technological innovations bring to creative activities, so that we can see in them a new way of creating, and how does a work of multivariate nature affect the viewer, evoking in him/her a peculiar perceptio sensatio.
The article presents an intermedia project based on distributed authorship, resulting from the collaboration of a music choreographer, a visual artist and a music theorist. Each of these people brings a different perspective and creation to the project, which integrates the guiding idea of "hearing and seeing" music, and even experiencing it multisensorially.
Syncretic activities on the borderline of composition, improvisation and interpretation of music and its choreography, as well as the conscious use of audiovisual objects, expand the fields of artistic activity to reach the audience through multiple channels of sensory perception. The spectator does not perceive isolated fields, because the sensory world is a synthesis of different fields of perception. The same object that we see, we can touch, can be a source of sound and smell. In this constellation, the intermedia narration of the work is not only an experiment that influences the attractiveness of the musical choreography presented, but also an object of research into a new language, the use of which expands the concept of thinking about the form of the composition presented. The amplified dimensions of the work's reception make it an attractive form of expression, which at the same time becomes an artistic-cognitive hybrid.

title: Four musical settings of the poem “In Danzig” by Joseph Eichendorff — music and the expression of the word

abstracts.content:
The poem In Danzig by Joseph Eichendorff, which appeared in the second edition of his works collected in 1848, is one of the most famous and important poems of the 19th century about Gdańsk. Its author, an important German poet of the Romantic era, has visited Gdańsk three times. From 1821 to 1824 he lived and worked here for the first time as a Prussian civil servant. In 1838, he spent several weeks in Gdansk with his eldest daughter. The last time he spent in the city was in the years 1843–1847 and lived with his family on Chlebnicka Street. At that time a poem was probably written in 1843 with the original title Nachts, later changed to Nachts in Danzig, finally entitled In Danzig. This outstanding example of German romantic poetry proved to be an important source of inspiration for the work of composers of different formats. The most well-known example of the song based on the poem comes from the work of Hans Pfitzner, the German composer of the turn of XIX/XX. I also noticed two other works on the Eichendorff text by lesser-known composers during the inquiry in the Gdańsk Library: Max Stange and Alfred Balfanz. The latter was Gdańsks citizen. The immediate impetus for dealing with this problem was the work of the young composer Kamil Cieślik with the eponymous title, which was premiered by the Gdańsk Vocal Ensemble Art’n”Voices. The object of the proposed reflection is therefore an attempt to compare the characteristics of the musical layer of the four works with regard to the expression of the poetic layer of Eichendorff’s poem. The thesis, which emerges in the initial stage of observation, follows intuition: the clarifications of the poem acquire a universal form to a certain extent. This means that the expression of the word
in the works depicted is of utmost importance for the music.

title: Inspiracje ukraińskie w twórczości fortepianowej Zygmunta Noskowskiego, ze szczególnym uwzględnieniem utworów na cztery ręce

otherTitles.title: Ukrainian inspirations in the piano works of Zygmunt Noskowski, with special emphasis on work for 4 hands

abstracts.content: The aim of this article is to show the sources of inspiration of Ukrainian folklore in the life and works of Zygmunt Noskowski (1846–1909) and to analyse the way in which this folklore is reflected in the Collection of Ukrainian Melodies op. 33. The author’s survey of Noskowski’s complete piano works makes it possible to determine the frequency of Ukrainian influences and to compare two– and four–handed works of a similar character. It also makes it possible to determine the composer’s preferences in terms of means of expression, use of piano figures and compositional techniques. A careful analysis of the ethnographic collections of Oskar Kolberg, Wacław of Olesko and other authors led to the identification of most of the quotations used in the op. 33 cycle. The available biographical literature indicates that the composer’s main place of residence was Warsaw, with the exception of two years of study in Berlin and several years of work in Konstanz. However, he regularly spent the summer months in the countryside, where he was interested in folklore. First it was Rokitnica, then near Krakow, where musicians from the Lviv Opera and actors from Stanislavov often performed. The borderlands of the former Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth and Galicia were closely linked culturally: the Lithuanian and Belarusian lands with Warsaw, Lviv and Stanislavov with Krakow. This may explain the “Slavic note” in the composer’s oeuvre, which goes beyond the typically Polish krakowiak, mazurka, polonaise, kujawiak and oberek. The infiltration of Ukrainian elements into Polish music was connected with the coexistence of these two cultures and nations. There is no doubt about Zygmunt Noskowski’s strong Polish national identity. In his miniature cycles, he showed the true richness of Polish culture, open to influences from across the border. For example, a polonaise and a krakowiak could appear in the same cycle alongside a trepak or a dumka.

title: Toccare, touche, artikulation. Wybrane zagadnienia artykulacyjne w muzyce organowej XVIII wieku

otherTitles.title: Toccare, Touche, Artikulation: Selected Articulation Issues in 18th-Century Organ Music

abstracts.content: Articulation is the most powerful element of creation in the 18th-century music for keyboard instruments. It is something very special that Polish tradition draws from German inclinations which include articulation as a part of speaking is quite opposite to the French/Italian understanding of the special creation of sound where the most important action is to touch the sound. When we start thinking about articulation as a type of touch, we can change many aspects ofs our interpretation. We do not know exactly how to create a successful articulation in old keyboard music because urtext editions do not contain symbols which could reveal how it should sound. Our next step is always the same: we want to know more so we start to read old treatises. This may be the most important thing in the creation of interpretation, but it is never enough. To learn the art of articulation in music better, we should look at famous cantatas and passions by Johann Sebastian Bach, especially at the Great Mass in B minor where he creates endless possibilities of how to play certain special motifs in Baroque music. The theoretical knowledge of the performer (and the psychoanalyst) allows the use of tried-and-tested methods of penetrating the unclear. However, it does not guarantee success. It is not the insight of analysis that allows them to captivate crowds but listening to the work in a way that allows them to share it with the audience.

title: Specyfika prowadzenia głosu w pieśniach kabaretowych Arnolda Schönberga (Brettl–Lieder) i Benjamina Brittena (Cabaret Songs)

otherTitles.title: The peculiarities of the voice leading in the cabaret songs of Arnold Schönberg (Brettl–Lieder) and Benjamin Britten (Cabaret Songs)

abstracts.content: The cabaret song form appeared at some point in the lives of the Austrian representative of dodecaphony in music, Arnold Schönberg (Sieben Brettl-Lieder), and the 39 years younger British composer, Benjamin Britten (Four Cabaret Songs), providing a very interesting compilation of cabaret lightness and classical technical perfection. This original music represents an interesting and fascinating trend in the oeuvre of these eminent composers inspiring ambitious singers around the world. Both cycles share good and original poetry. In Schönberg’s case, it is the lyric poetry of German poets writing with the developing literary cabaret in mind, while in Britten’s, the philosophical and existential poetry of Wystan Hugh Auden, his mentor and friend. The author analyses not only the musical and literary layer of the songs, but discusses in detail the right kind of interpretation, the specific aspect of voice leading, the style of performance and all the nuances of the artistic interpretation of these songs. She analyses Schönberg’s characteristic Sprechgesang style as well as Britten’s swinging style with virtuosic elements and a wide vocal range.

title: Liryka wokalna Benjamina Brittena

otherTitles.title: Benjamin Britten's vocal lyrics

abstracts.content: This article takes us into the markedly different world of sound of the creator of 20th-century musical aesthetics, the pianist and composer Benjamin Britten who, through his original work, secured a prominent place in music history. The human voice inspired him in a  special way, hence the great number of vocal works in his music. The author shares with the readers her great fascination with Britten’s oeuvre, which she has expressed in both her doctoral and post-doctoral dissertations. She produces a  certain catalogue of songs by the great Englishman, discussing the different phases in the development of the composer’s style, exposing all kinds of progressions. She also analyses his song cycles with their musical and poetic material, delving into the relationships between music and word, as well as into the pianistic layer.

title: Obraz grzechu w muzyce barokowej na przykładzie kantaty Widerstehe doch der Sünde BWV 54 Johanna Sebastiana Bacha

otherTitles.title: The Portrayal of Sin in Baroque Music: A Case Study of Johann Sebastian Bach’s Cantata ‘Widerstehe doch der Sünde’ BWV 54

abstracts.content: In the musical activity of Johann Sebastian Bach, Cantatas – in which the portrayal of sin is often present – occupy a special place. In the general perception, in the late Baroque period, the male alto was treated as a symbol of a converted sinner. It was to the alto voice that the composer most often entrusted arias in which the lyrical subject was identified with an internally torn sinner. In order to understand the musical message hidden in Bach’s vocal-instrumental works, the article outlines the nature of sin in the light of theological and philosophical reflections. The perception of this issue is juxtaposed with the theology of the Evangelical Church, in the spirit of Johann Sebastian Bach. In the final part of the article, the solo cantata for solo voice – alto – Widerstehe doch der Sünde BWV 54 was analysed in terms of the interpenetration of the verbal and musical layers.

title: Feliks Nowowiejski i jego twórczość mszalna – prawie zapomniana karta w chóralistyce sakralnej

otherTitles.title: Feliks Nowowiejski and His Masses: An All But Forgotten Chapter in Sacred Choralism

abstracts.content: Feliks Nowowiejski’s masses are considered some of the most valuable works in the 20th century Polish music; however, apart from Missa pro Pace, they are known to a small group of specialists: conductors, musicologists and other researchers of Polish musical culture. The aim of this paper is to present the largely unknown masses by Feliks Nowowiejski. Covers are the general characteristics of nine mass cycles written in the first half of the 20th century and their reception by the musical community. The description includes the circumstances of their creation, construction, liturgical language used, availability of musical material and other information.

title: Czas linearny i nielinearny w utworze Hanny Kulenty A Third Circle na fortepian solo

otherTitles.title: Linear and Non-linear Time in A Third Circle for Solo Piano by Hanna Kulenty

abstracts.content: According to Jonathan D. Kramer’s concept, time in a musical work is organized based on two complementary structural forces: linearity and non-linearity. The characteristics of temporality of a specific composition are, to a large degree, a result of how and to what extent those two forces pervade and complete each other. The objective of the analysis of A Third Circle by Hanna Kulenty is to determine, through examination of pitch, rhythm and texture, the ways in which said coexistence of linearity and non-linearity manifests itself. What makes this small-scale piano work particularly inspiring for this kind of research is the combination of repetitiveness and tendency to constantly build and heighten the tension; both being essential features of the composer’s individual musical language.

title: Dzieło zapisane a dzieło zaimprowizowane – różnice ekspresyjne i stylistyczne na przykładzie twórczości Charlesa Tournemire’a

otherTitles.title: A Written Work versus an Improvised Work. Differences in Expression and Style as Illustrated by Charles Tournemire’s Oeuvre

abstracts.content: The art of improvisation seems to be the earliest manifestation of human artistic activity. Over the centuries in a gesture of free expression of his emotions, beliefs and ideas, man has crossed the boundaries of the known, stable world in order to fulfill the inner compulsion to create in an inconceivable structure of imagination through abstract works. The improvised work is a clear testimony to the spontaneous message, expression, following the inspiration of a given moment, which also makes it a strong impulse in the context of the interpretation of the written work. Therefore, they are complementary creations, coexisting in the collective consciousness of composers, improvisers and sensitive recipients alike, who create a space for experiencing the deepest mysteries of existence in an elaborate structure developing live. The works and improvisations of the French composer Charles Tournemire – the last student of César Franck, as well as his successor as the titular organist of St Clotilde’s Church in Paris at the famous Aristide Cavaillé-Colla organ – contain good material for research in this area. Tournemire was primarily remembered for his improvisations, in which he presented an immense wealth of imagination and creative freedom.

title: Quatre Mendiants et Quatre Hors d’Oeuvres – w muzycznym salonie Gioachino Rossiniego

otherTitles.title: Quatre Mendiants et Quatre Hors d’Oeuvres – in Gioachino Rossini’s Music Salon

abstracts.content: From among the 109 works by Rossini originally written for piano, the vast majority (101) were written at the end of the composer’s life between 1857 and 1868. 95 of them, along with other instrumental and vocal compositions, he collected and arranged in thirteen volumes under one title, Sins of Old Age. Rossini’s typical sense of humour coupled with his distance from creativity and himself is visible in many of them. However, it manifests itself in a special way in the fourth volume of the collection, Quatre Mendiants et Quatre Hors d’Oeuvres. In France, the term ‘mendiants’ defined four types of dried fruit and nuts: figs, almonds, raisins and hazelnuts; such are also the titles of the subsequent works by Rossini. For the set of four Hors d’Oeuvres, or snacks, Rossini chose ‘Les radis’ (radishes), ‘Les anchovies’ (anchovy preserves), ‘Les cornichons’ (gherkins) and ‘La beurre’ (butter). This seemingly ‘gastronomic’ album, especially its first part, is in fact a very personal, musical depiction of everyday home life presented with a playful wink. Learning these works better, it is easy to understand why the acknowledged master, who had been silent in the field of opera for years, would not agree to publish his latest works. In the outside musical world of the time, in the moment of triumph of the music by Wagner, Brahms and Schumann, his intimate, playful compositions were something unique. At the same time, however, the latter did not follow the dominant style. Enjoying great fame and fortune, Rossini could afford to put his compositions on the shelf, as it were, presenting his works only to a small group of friends and guests invited to the composer’s villa in Passy. The first complete edition of Quatre Mendiants et Quatre Hors d’Oeuvres was published thanks to Fondazione Rossini in Pesaro as late as in 1976.

title: Pneumatologiczny wymiar sztuki improwizacji w muzyce kościelnej

otherTitles.title: The Pneumatological Dimension of the Art of Improvisation in Church Music

abstracts.content: There are many facets to musical improvisation not only in specifically musical but also philosophical, psychological, sociological and pedagogical terms, as well as in terms of musical improvisation in the performance dimension and therapy. Since the beginnings of Christianity, improvisation has played an important role in church music. Therefore, it is also perfectly legitimate to perform a theological, especially pneumatological (from the Greek pneuma meaning ‘spirit’and logos meaning ‘word’ or ‘science’) analysis of this art in religious music in its broad sense, especially that which is associated with the liturgical expression of the Christian faith. In considering this question, it is necessary first to emphasize the role of the Holy Spirit as a source of artistic inspiration, and then to examine the phenomena that have accompanied the musical prayer of Christians since the apostolic times: glossolalia, ‘singing in tongues’ and music as the ‘language of angels’. This biblical and theological reflection represents an attempt to identify the source of musical improvisation, namely the dialogue between the creator man and the creator God, held in the depths of the artist’s soul.

title: Zmierzch Bogów. Claude-Bénigne Balbastre – muzyka organowa czasów rewolucji

otherTitles.title: Twilight of the Gods. Claude-Bénigne Balbastre – the Organ Music of the Revolutionary Times

abstracts.content: Old French music used to be confined to the once coined term ‘golden age’ covering the years 1600–1789. However, during these nearly two hundred years French art underwent as significant stylistic changes as the rest of Europe. It is difficult to compare Titelouze’s early works with the music of composers of the late Enlightenment. The obvious connections between the emergence of these artists and a specific tradition are based on a common denominator which is the characteristic French organ of that time and on a specific, emblematic way of selecting voices and using colours. However, musical ideas underwent major transformations, and the political situation left its mark on the musical language of the composers of the second half of the 18th century. Social demand changed the recipient from the elitist to the egalitarian who interpreted all courtliness as a connection with the system against which successive states rebelled. Little is said about the situation of organ music during the revolution, except that the revival of this art was the establishment of a new school led by Cesar Franck and Jacques Nicolaus Lemmens. The situation of church music, including organ music, was extremely precarious because the church as an institution became one of the targets of the revolutionaries’ attacks. Ending with the outbreak of the French Revolution, the organ music of the second half of the 18th century is characterized by the simplification of means of expression, striving for the greatest possible clarity and readability.

title: Polifonia w białoruskiej muzyce fortepianowej na przełomie XX–XXI w.

otherTitles.title: Polyphony in Belarusian Piano Music at the Turn of the 21st Century

abstracts.content: Belarusian music is an integral part of European musical culture. But many of its aspects still require more detailed consideration and coverage in musicological publications. The article is devoted to studying the polyphony in the Belarusian piano music at the turn of the 21st century. The purpose of the research was to show the specific aesthetic and technical qualities of polyphony in the creative activity of different generations of composers. The research subject was the music collection Полифонические произведения белорусских композиторов для фортепиано (‘Polyphonic Works for Piano by Belarusian Composers’) published in 2019. It contains opuses by composers who began to write in different decades of the 20th and 21st centuries. This article contains a brief historical overview of musical culture, providing the context of the emergence of polyphony in Belarusian piano music. The artistic content of the compositions correlated with the poetics of postmodernism in its various manifestations. Methods of musicological and comparative analysis were used in the course of the study. The research results reveal that the composers’ aesthetic foundations are different. Yet, in general, Belarusian composers interpret polyphonic techniques and forms within the framework of European musical art.

title: Czy istnieje okres krytyczny w nauce śpiewu?

otherTitles.title: Is There a Critical Period in Learning Singing?

abstracts.content: The subject of the paper is a consideration of the critical period in learning singing, the importance of singing in a child's life, and a discussion of certain initiatives for fostering early music education. The author presents the results of studies conducted by Peretz (2006), Trainor (2006), Shahin et al. (2004), Stadler (2012), A. Weiner (2010), Dalla Bella and Berkowska (2009) and reports some of the results of studies demonstrating the corelation between the critical period and later musical achievements. The author refers to reports in the literature that emphasize the importance of singing in a child's life, reports on the results of studies that favour strengthening the emotional bond between careers and children (Trehub, 1997), emphasize the connection between singing and health (Blank, Adamek, 2010), point out the social value of vocal activities (Welch et al., 2014), and discusses the impact of early music education on brain plasticity (Halwani et al., 2011). She also presents certain programmers aimed at vocal stimulation of children (the Il Canto del mondo - Internationales Netzwerk zur Förderung der Alltagskulturen des Singens e.V.initiative, conducted in Germany) and characterizes the four-year Music Manifesto singing program, which was extended to all achoolchildren in England between 2024 and 2008. She concludes by pointing to educational neglect in the Polish educational system, as a result of which 27% of children completing the third year in mainstream achools, i.e. beyond the critical period for learning to sing, are monotone children.

title: Znaczenie kontaktów z muzyką w świetle współczesnych doniesień nauki

otherTitles.title: The Importance of Contact with Music in the Light of Current Research

abstracts.content: The article is based on international and national research results highlighting the relationship between musical ear and cognitive abilities, most notably memory. The author discusses the neurobiological foundations of musical interventions, the biochemical and biodynamic foundations of musical reactions as well as the anatomical and neural effects of music education, the relationship between practical musical training and the development of synaptic networks in children. She extensively discusses the research results showing the benefits of practical musical activities and their impact on the development of linguistic and mathematical skills. It highlights the relationship between music education and cognitive faculties (intelligence, memory and attention) and characterizes the impact of musical activities on the development in emotional and social aspects. She is also interested in the therapeutic possibilities of musical activities. In conclusion, she emphasizes the relationship between musical ear and higher-order thought processes, mainly memory, the impact of practical musical instrument training, the hidden therapeutic, emotional and social function of musical activities observed in empirical research.

title: Dorobek naukowy gdańskiego środowiska akademickiego w zakresie wczesnej edukacji muzycznej

otherTitles.title: Scientific Achievements of the Gdańsk Academic Community in the Field of Early Childhood Music Education

abstracts.content: The knowledge and spread of scientific literature on early childhood music education, whose authors come from the academic community in Gdańsk (mainly from Stanisław Moniuszko Academy of Music and the University of Gdańsk) is rather limited. The author – pointing at the possible reasons for this situation – presents the titular issue in its historical aspect. The 1970s are shown as the beginning of the formation of a group of scientists interested in the issues of early childhood music education. In this context, she emphasizes the importance of the creation and development of logorhythmics in the Gdańsk center and the initiation of international contacts by Elżbieta Kilińska (including inviting Batia Strauss to conduct the first workshop in Poland in 1993 and establishing cooperation with the Carl Orff Institute in Salzburg). The author emphasizes that the first works of Kinga Lewandowska in the field of psychology of music and music therapy were also published in this period. These works were summarized in the monograph Children’s music therapy in 1996. However, the author presents the last twenty years as a crucial and busy period, since the Gdańsk community intensified its research, organization and the publishing of works in the area of early childhood music education, which resulted in e.g. a series of important science conferences in Poland (“The Pedagogy of Music: Features, Axiology, Systematics” and “The Issues of Early Childhood Music Education”) as well as interesting and often innovative research and publications on a national scale conducted by scientists affiliated with the Academy of Music in Gdańsk (including Alicja Kozłowska-Lewna, Michał Kierzkowski, Alina Kowalska-Pińczak, Elżbieta Frołowicz, Katarzyna Kierzkowska) and the University of Gdańsk (Rafał Lawendowski, Ilona Poćwierz-Marciniak, Ewa Szatan).

title: Artistic Ekphrasis and Inphrasis. A Term in the Studies of Intermedial Works

abstracts.content:
From the concert hall to the museum, from the street to private spaces, from live contexts to listening to recordings, from television to streaming systems, listening to music is today a subject that deserves our attention. Discussing music listening is crucial due to the diverse genres and sound art practices, as sound, music, and noise are omnipresent, shaping our environment and profoundly impacting our daily lives. In 2020, UNESCO recognized music’s role in cognitive development, learning, memorization, and skill acquisition. Listeners navigate a complex, saturated musical landscape with diverse streams and listening options.

Passive uniformity, reduced concentration, aversion to complexity, cultural isolation, and limited engagement shape modern music listening and our environment. Over one billion young people risk hearing loss due to loud music. How does constant sound affect our focus and listening? Can sound and music be seen as pollution? How can sound ecology address this, and what role does music play in today’s sonic landscape, impacting society?

Composers and performers are increasingly interested in listening to their own compositions and performances. In the latter half of the 20th century, space emerged as an integral musical parameter, with figures such as Stockhausen, Xenakis, Lucier, and many others contributing to this development. Today, the perceptual and cognitive potential of music pieces represents a new frontier for exploration. To what extent does listening influence the creative process? Can new listening modalities enhance our approach to historical music?

In a performative context, new listening situations are on the rise. Audiences and performers are actively engaged in innovative auditory experiences, including multimodal, virtual, and immersive encounters. How do these listening modalities influence the appreciation of a musical piece? To what extent is the listening process influenced or restricted by the context in which it occurs? What role does music listening play in settings like museum exhibitions, sound installations, or sound art events? What are the purposes and potentials of music listening in public and open spaces?
